body.name: The Heiress: A Novel
body.description: This program features multicast narration. New York Times bestselling author Rachel Hawkins returns with a twisted new gothic suspense about an infamous heiress and the complicated inheritance she left behind. THERE’S NOTHING AS GOOD AS THE RICH GONE BAD When Ruby McTavish Callahan Woodward Miller Kenmore dies, she’s not only North Carolina’s richest woman, she’s also its most notorious. The victim of a famous kidnapping as a child and a widow four times over, Ruby ruled the tiny town of Tavistock from Ashby House, her family’s estate high in the Blue Ridge Mountains. But in the aftermath of her death, her adopted son, Camden, wants little to do with the house or the money—and even less to do with the surviving McTavishes. Instead, he rejects his inheritance, settling into a normal life as an English teacher in Colorado and marrying Jules, a woman just as eager to escape her own messy past. Ten years later, his uncle’s death pulls Cam and Jules back into the family fold at Ashby House. Its views are just as stunning as ever, its rooms just as elegant, but the legacy of Ruby is inescapable. And as Ashby House tightens its grip on Jules and Camden, questions about the infamous heiress come to light. Was there any truth to the persistent rumors following her disappearance as a girl? What really happened to those four husbands, who all died under mysterious circumstances? And why did she adopt Cam in the first place? Soon, Jules and Cam realize that an inheritance can entail far more than what’s written in a will—and that the bonds of family stretch far beyond the grave. A Macmillan Audio production from St. Martin’s Press. Read more

productInformation.name: Narrator
productInformation.value: Dan Bittner, Eliza Foss, John Pirhalla, Patti Murin

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on January 16, 2024
reviews.reviewTitle: 5.0 out of 5 stars THRILLING CAT & MOUSE GAME...
reviews.reviewText: When Ruby McTavish Callahan Woodward Miller Kenmore dies, she’s not only North Carolina’s richest woman, she’s also its most notorious. The victim of a famous kidnapping as a child and a widow four times over, Ruby ruled the tiny town of Tavistock from Ashby House, her family’s estate high in the Blue Ridge Mountains.But in the aftermath of her death, her adopted son, Camden, wants little to do with the house or the money—and even less to do with the surviving McTavishes. Instead, he rejects his inheritance, settling into a normal life as an English teacher in Colorado and marrying Jules, a woman just as eager to escape her own messy past.Ten years later, his uncle’s death pulls Cam and Jules back into the family fold at Ashby House. Its views are just as stunning as ever, its rooms just as elegant, but the legacy of Ruby is inescapable.And as Ashby House tightens its grip on Jules and Camden, questions about the infamous heiress come to light. Was there any truth to the persistent rumors following her disappearance as a girl? What really happened to those four husbands, who all died under mysterious circumstances? And why did she adopt Cam in the first place? Soon, Jules and Cam realize that an inheritance can entail far more than what’s written in a will––and that the bonds of family stretch far beyond the grave.My Thoughts:In The Heiress, the reader finds a puzzling and intriguing story of a family, its dark secrets, and the manipulations that cloak them all.When Camden and Jules finally go to Ashby House to deal with the inheritance, we learn a lot, as do they, and through a series of letters, we also begin to see how the past has gripped them all and held them captive.I was stunned at each new development, via the letters and other methods of unlocking the truths, to finally learn what had kept the family bound together. A great five star read.***

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on January 30, 2024
reviews.reviewTitle: 4.0 out of 5 stars Great plot and characters
reviews.reviewText: I love Rachel Hawkins's books, and "The Heiress" is no exception. Ruby made me think of Evelyn Hugo but murder-y. This family is toxic in the most entertaining way, and there are so many twists and betrayals to keep you hooked in the story. The letters were my favorite chapters, but I liked how the plot unfolded in the others. The audiobook had a good cast of narrators that really brought the characters to life, even if the accents were a little off at times.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on February 4, 2024
reviews.reviewTitle: 5.0 out of 5 stars The Story of Stories
reviews.reviewText: An amazing read...from start to finish. The Heiress focuses on the life and story of Ruby McTavish, through the perspectives of her letters, her son, Camden, and his wife, Jules. As the story unfolds, you realize that Cam and Jules's connection is deeper than their 10-year marriage. As the two return to Cam's home, the Ashby House, Jules learns more about the family that her husband tried to escape. The plot twists will grip you until you find yourself reading the final pages. I would rate this book 10 stars if I could. I thoroughly enjoyed it.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on February 11, 2024
reviews.reviewText: I have purchased two of the author's contemporary books. I know a lot of people in all stages of their lives and I never hear the F words that she uses so liberally. The stories are good but she could do them without all of the F words which add nothing to the plot.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on February 3, 2024
reviews.reviewText: This is one of those dysfunctional family stories in which the story continues getting worse instead of better. I did like some of the characters in the beginning, but by the end of the book, I did not like any of them very well. I usually hope that someone will be the "good" character that wins in the end, but that's not this book.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on January 29, 2024
reviews.reviewTitle: 5.0 out of 5 stars Great plot twists, engaging all the way to the end.
reviews.reviewText: I have read Rachel Hawkins books before and knew I could count on her to write a good read. I was right. I find there are some novels where the author is transported to another realm beyond their own experience and Ms. Hawkins was clearly transported. The characters were interesting, the plot twists surprising and the whole novel held my attention all the way to the end.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on February 11, 2024
reviews.reviewTitle: 4.0 out of 5 stars Lots of twists and turns
reviews.reviewText: I really enjoyed this book! Much more than The Villa personally :) in fact I didn’t want to read this book but it was next in line in my book club and I ended up being pleasantly surprised.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on January 13, 2024
reviews.reviewTitle: 5.0 out of 5 stars Great mystery thriller
reviews.reviewText: WOWZA!! Life of the uber rich is NOT what it’s cracked up to be.. with greed, revenge, lies + murder.. the McTavish family are ruthless. To say I was highly entertained is an understatement. Rachel Hawkins has written an addictive story that had me hooked from the get go. The North Carolina setting was perfect.. so atmospheric.. with the remote McTavish “Ashby House” sitting amongst thick wooded forests and the rough terrain of the Blue Ridge Mountains giving this novel all the gothic feels. A fantastic mystery-thriller with a wild, surprising twist. 5 stars — Pub. 1/9/24

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on January 22, 2024
reviews.reviewText: I really enjoyed this book and couldn’t put it down. The structure with alternating chapters about Jules and Camden is great with Ruby’s letters woven in between so easy to follow and the plot is brilliant. Loved the twist at the end.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on February 3, 2024
reviews.reviewTitle: Didn't enjoy it but I know others who have!
reviews.reviewText: The characters felt quite like caricatures and the plot was outlandish enough not to be realistic whilst not wild enough to be fantastical.
